item.title: Ask
Listen
item.description: This is not about you being right and them being wrong. Try to understand their concerns and motivations. Ask more open questions. If they have many concerns, focus on the biggest first.

item.title: Reflect
item.description: Show you understand. Repeat back what they have said to show that you have really heard what they have to say. For example: ‘So, you are worried that the NHS is falling appart?’

item.title: Agree
item.description: Find common ground. This may not be easy at first but if you focus on their goals and emotions you will probably find something in common. For example: ‘I agree, I’m realy worried that in the future the NHS won’t be there for me and my family.’

item.title: Discuss
item.description: Share your personal point of view. Focus on the personal impact of Brexit on you or your family. How does this subject impact you and your family? For example: Less money for the NHS ‘We are not going to get the extra £350 million a week for the NHS that we were promised. Even Nigel Farage said he could not guarantee we would get that money. How is the NHS going to be there for me and my family with less money?
